page.title: 12TEMPLE NORMANTON'S CHURCHES.
page.content: There has been a place of worship in Temple Normanton since the twelfth century but it is believed the first church was built in 1623. It is described as a plain oblong building with a clumsy wooden bell turret. The second church of St. James was erected in 1882 on the same foundation It became unsafe due to colliery subsidence and was demolished in 1921. Coal mining had been carried out within the area for over a 100 years and records show nine seams beneath the church itself. Again on the same site a 'temporary' wooden church was built in 1923. This was also affected by subsidence and damaged by gales and demolished as unsafe in 1982. Work on the fourth church built on the same site began in the spring of 1985 and will be completed by the end of the year.
